headline.plaintext: About 70% of stations in Charlotte, North Carolina, are out of gas

content.plaintext: In the Charlotte, North Carolina, area, "a significant percentage of gas station" are without gas, Charlotte-Mecklenburg Emergency Management spokesperson Hannah Sanborn tells CNN.
content.richtext: In the Charlotte, North Carolina, area, "a significant percentage of gas station" are without gas, Charlotte-Mecklenburg Emergency Management spokesperson Hannah Sanborn tells CNN.

content.plaintext: The exact numbers of empty gas stations "is very dynamic and changing constantly," Sanborn said, but she added that about 70% of stations do not have gas.
content.richtext: The exact numbers of empty gas stations "is very dynamic and changing constantly," Sanborn said, but she added that about 70% of stations do not have gas.

headline.plaintext: Transportation secretary warns against hoarding and improperly storing gasoline

paragraphs.text: US Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg, with Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency Michael Regan, speaks in the Brady Briefing Room during the daily White House briefing on May 12, in Washington.

caption.richtext: US Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg, with Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency Michael Regan, speaks in the Brady Briefing Room during the daily White House briefing on May 12, in Washington.
caption.plaintext: US Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg, with Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency Michael Regan, speaks in the Brady Briefing Room during the daily White House briefing on May 12, in Washington.

content.plaintext: Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg warned against hoarding or improper storage of gasoline, following reports that a growing number of gas stations along the East Coast are without fuel following a ransomware attack that shut down the Colonial Pipeline, a critical artery for gasoline.
content.richtext: Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg warned against hoarding or improper storage of gasoline, following reports that a growing number of gas stations along the East Coast are without fuel following a ransomware attack that shut down the Colonial Pipeline, a critical artery for gasoline.

content.plaintext: “I will say that this is a time to be sensible and to be safe,” Buttigieg told reporters at Wednesday’s White House briefing. “Of course, we understand the concern in the areas where people are encountering temporary supply disruptions, but hoarding does not make things better.”
content.richtext: “I will say that this is a time to be sensible and to be safe,” Buttigieg told reporters at Wednesday’s White House briefing. “Of course, we understand the concern in the areas where people are encountering temporary supply disruptions, but hoarding does not make things better.”

content.plaintext: In a series of tweets Wednesday, the US Consumer Product Safety Commission warned, among other things, to “not fill plastic bags with gasoline,” despite shortages.
content.richtext: In a series of tweets Wednesday, the US Consumer Product Safety Commission warned, among other things, to “not fill plastic bags with gasoline,” despite shortages.

content.plaintext: “And under no circumstances should gasoline ever be put into anything but a vehicle directly or an approved container, and that of course, remains true no matter what else is going on,” Buttigieg said Wednesday.
content.richtext: “And under no circumstances should gasoline ever be put into anything but a vehicle directly or an approved container, and that of course, remains true no matter what else is going on,” Buttigieg said Wednesday.

content.plaintext: He also pushed back against the notion that the administration was considering taking over management of the Colonial Pipeline to restore service, telling reporters, “I've not heard anything along those lines. We are partnering with the company to make sure that on everything, from the flexibilities we talked about to technical support and advice, that they're getting the help they need, and they have been able through foreign and ancillary lines to move some product although, again, obviously, waiting for determination on fully reopening.”
content.richtext: He also pushed back against the notion that the administration was considering taking over management of the Colonial Pipeline to restore service, telling reporters, “I've not heard anything along those lines. We are partnering with the company to make sure that on everything, from the flexibilities we talked about to technical support and advice, that they're getting the help they need, and they have been able through foreign and ancillary lines to move some product although, again, obviously, waiting for determination on fully reopening.”

headline.plaintext: Costco official says gas supply at fueling stations is "touch-and-go"

paragraphs.text: Cars line up to fill their gas tanks at a COSTCO at Tyvola Road in Charlotte, North Carolina on May 11.

caption.richtext: Cars line up to fill their gas tanks at a COSTCO at Tyvola Road in Charlotte, North Carolina on May 11.
caption.plaintext: Cars line up to fill their gas tanks at a COSTCO at Tyvola Road in Charlotte, North Carolina on May 11.

content.plaintext: Gas supply at Costco filling stations around the Southeast are mostly holding, but as panic-buying continues in the wake of the Colonial Pipeline cyberattack, that could change.
content.richtext: Gas supply at Costco filling stations around the Southeast are mostly holding, but as panic-buying continues in the wake of the Colonial Pipeline cyberattack, that could change.

content.plaintext: Yoram Rubanenko, Costco senior vice president of operations for the Southeast, told CNN Wednesday the situation is increasingly “touch-and-go.”
content.richtext: Yoram Rubanenko, Costco senior vice president of operations for the Southeast, told CNN Wednesday the situation is increasingly “touch-and-go.”

content.plaintext: “The lines are crazy for gas,” Rubanenko said. “Our supply is okay right now but it’s touch and go. We’re so busy at the moment that at a place we have enough fuel right now, we may be out in the next few hours.”
content.richtext: “The lines are crazy for gas,” Rubanenko said. “Our supply is okay right now but it’s touch and go. We’re so busy at the moment that at a place we have enough fuel right now, we may be out in the next few hours.”

content.plaintext: Rubanenko said in the state of Georgia, one fueling station in Alpharetta is totally out of gas while locations in Cumming and Peachtree City are very low.
content.richtext: Rubanenko said in the state of Georgia, one fueling station in Alpharetta is totally out of gas while locations in Cumming and Peachtree City are very low.

content.plaintext: "It’s going to be touch-and-go until the pipeline gets back to normal,” Rubanenko said, noting that some gas stations will not be offering premium gas until supply is restored.
content.richtext: "It’s going to be touch-and-go until the pipeline gets back to normal,” Rubanenko said, noting that some gas stations will not be offering premium gas until supply is restored.

content.plaintext: Rubanenko said the panic-buying goes from Maryland down the eastern seaboard, and the situation is constantly evolving.
content.richtext: Rubanenko said the panic-buying goes from Maryland down the eastern seaboard, and the situation is constantly evolving.

content.plaintext: “It’s changing. Every day it's changing,” he said.
content.richtext: “It’s changing. Every day it's changing,” he said.

content.plaintext: Rubanenko said the company is only imposing fuel limits on people showing up with extra gas containers. The limit, he said, is two containers.
content.richtext: Rubanenko said the company is only imposing fuel limits on people showing up with extra gas containers. The limit, he said, is two containers.

headline.plaintext: These states are reporting the most gas stations with fuel outages

content.plaintext: GasBuddy, an app that tracks fuel demand, prices and outages, has released updated figures on the gas shortages in some Southeastern US states.
content.richtext: GasBuddy, an app that tracks fuel demand, prices and outages, has released updated figures on the gas shortages in some Southeastern US states.

content.plaintext: As of 11 a.m. ET, here's the percentage of all gas stations without gasoline:
content.richtext: As of 11 a.m. ET, here's the percentage of all gas stations without gasoline:

content.plaintext:
28.2% in North Carolina
17.5% in Georgia
17.1% in Virginia 
16.2% in South Carolina 
4.6% in Florida  
4.1% in Maryland 
3.6% in Tennessee 
2.8% in West Virginia
content.richtext:
• 28.2% in North Carolina
  • 17.5% in Georgia
  • 17.1% in Virginia
  • 16.2% in South Carolina
  • 4.6% in Florida
  • 4.1% in Maryland
  • 3.6% in Tennessee
  • 2.8% in West Virginia

headline.plaintext: North Carolina governor has no plans to impose statewide limits on buying gas

content.plaintext: North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper addressed the on-going fuel shortages at some gas stations across the Southeast Wednesday saying it was “solely related to panic-buying.”
content.richtext: North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper addressed the on-going fuel shortages at some gas stations across the Southeast Wednesday saying it was “solely related to panic-buying.”

content.plaintext: “The shortages we are seeing are pretty much solely related to panic-buying from people and I want to encourage people not to do that. Don’t fill up your car unless you have to,” Cooper said during a news conference following an economic announcement Wednesday.
content.richtext: “The shortages we are seeing are pretty much solely related to panic-buying from people and I want to encourage people not to do that. Don’t fill up your car unless you have to,” Cooper said during a news conference following an economic announcement Wednesday.

content.plaintext: The governor said he has no plans to impose limits on fuel statewide.
content.richtext: The governor said he has no plans to impose limits on fuel statewide.

content.plaintext: Cooper said he has been in touch with US Energy Secretary Jennifer Granholm and other federal officials about the gas shortages resulting from the Colonial Pipeline cyber-attack. He said the state has received a waiver from the United States Environmental Protection Agency allowing for the shipment of more fuel. He said Colonial is working to manually get fuel through one of its pipelines and into the state.
content.richtext: Cooper said he has been in touch with US Energy Secretary Jennifer Granholm and other federal officials about the gas shortages resulting from the Colonial Pipeline cyber-attack. He said the state has received a waiver from the United States Environmental Protection Agency allowing for the shipment of more fuel. He said Colonial is working to manually get fuel through one of its pipelines and into the state.

content.plaintext: In the meantime, the governor said his office working with gas stations to ensure there is fuel available for public safety throughout the state. He said many North Carolina public safety departments have their own gasoline supplies.
content.richtext: In the meantime, the governor said his office working with gas stations to ensure there is fuel available for public safety throughout the state. He said many North Carolina public safety departments have their own gasoline supplies.

headline.plaintext: At 3 US Army bases, you can now buy only 10 gallons of gas

byline.plaintext: From CNN's Paul Murphy, Dianne Gallagher, and Barbara Starr
byline.richtext: From CNN's Paul Murphy, Dianne Gallagher, and Barbara Starr

paragraphs.text: A sign leads people to Fort Bragg Army Base on June 13, 2020.

caption.richtext: A sign leads people to Fort Bragg Army Base on June 13, 2020.
caption.plaintext: A sign leads people to Fort Bragg Army Base on June 13, 2020.

content.plaintext: Gas shortages, fueled by panic-buying, have forced three US Army installations in Georgia, North Carolina, and Virginia to limit gas purchases for on-base customers to 10 gallons.
content.richtext: Gas shortages, fueled by panic-buying, have forced three US Army installations in Georgia, North Carolina, and Virginia to limit gas purchases for on-base customers to 10 gallons.

content.plaintext: According to three posts on social media, the Army bases in Fort Bragg, North Carolina; Fort Lee, Virginia; and Fort Gordon, Georgia, have imposed the limits.
content.richtext: According to three posts on social media, the Army bases in Fort Bragg, North Carolina; Fort Lee, Virginia; and Fort Gordon, Georgia, have imposed the limits.

content.plaintext: Fort Lee also stopped overnight fueling, in addition to the 10-gallon limit. At Fort Bragg, employees are being asked to check in about telework options, especially those that may have a long commute.
content.richtext: Fort Lee also stopped overnight fueling, in addition to the 10-gallon limit. At Fort Bragg, employees are being asked to check in about telework options, especially those that may have a long commute.

content.plaintext: Fort Bragg also warned that they have "limited" fuel left, but said they anticipated three tankers full of gas will arrive today to refuel the station on base.
content.richtext: Fort Bragg also warned that they have "limited" fuel left, but said they anticipated three tankers full of gas will arrive today to refuel the station on base.

content.plaintext: CNN has reached out to the Department of Defense for comment and has asked whether this was the result of a regional directive to preserve gas supplies.
content.richtext: CNN has reached out to the Department of Defense for comment and has asked whether this was the result of a regional directive to preserve gas supplies.

headline.plaintext: Gas panic "spreading virally" with Virginia becoming "ground zero," expert says

content.plaintext: A gas expert tells CNN “ground zero” for the rush to buy gas is now in Virginia, with sales at some gas station chains 50% to 60% greater than normal.
content.richtext: A gas expert tells CNN “ground zero” for the rush to buy gas is now in Virginia, with sales at some gas station chains 50% to 60% greater than normal.

content.plaintext: Tom Kloza of the Oil Price Information Service says panic behavior brought on by fears that there could be a shortage of gas caused by the Colonial Pipeline hack is “spreading virally.”
content.richtext: Tom Kloza of the Oil Price Information Service says panic behavior brought on by fears that there could be a shortage of gas caused by the Colonial Pipeline hack is “spreading virally.”

content.plaintext: “It’s spreading like a bad rash,” Kloza said, with posts on social media show long lines at gas stations in the DC metro suburb of Arlington. Gov. Ralph Northam declared a state of emergency in Virginia on Tuesday.
content.richtext: “It’s spreading like a bad rash,” Kloza said, with posts on social media show long lines at gas stations in the DC metro suburb of Arlington. Gov. Ralph Northam declared a state of emergency in Virginia on Tuesday.

content.plaintext: A GasBuddy map shows more stations in Virginia running low on higher octane gas. “If you want premium, good luck with that,” Kloza said.
content.richtext: A GasBuddy map shows more stations in Virginia running low on higher octane gas. “If you want premium, good luck with that,” Kloza said.

content.plaintext: On Tuesday, Energy Secretary Jennifer Granholm classified the fears as unfounded — rather a “supply crunch” than a gas shortage.
content.richtext: On Tuesday, Energy Secretary Jennifer Granholm classified the fears as unfounded — rather a “supply crunch” than a gas shortage.

headline.plaintext: These cities are reporting the most gas station outages

paragraphs.text: A sign warns consumers on the availability of gasoline at a RaceTrac gas station on May 11, in Smyrna, Georgia.

caption.richtext: A sign warns consumers on the availability of gasoline at a RaceTrac gas station on May 11, in Smyrna, Georgia.
caption.plaintext: A sign warns consumers on the availability of gasoline at a RaceTrac gas station on May 11, in Smyrna, Georgia.

content.plaintext: Gas stations throughout the Southeast are running out of fuel as Americans continue to panic-buy following the Colonial Pipeline shutdown.
content.richtext: Gas stations throughout the Southeast are running out of fuel as Americans continue to panic-buy following the Colonial Pipeline shutdown.

content.plaintext: The supply crunch appears to be much worse in some major metro areas. Here's a look at some of the hardest-hit cities, according to GasBuddy, an app that tracks fuel demand, prices and outages.
content.richtext: The supply crunch appears to be much worse in some major metro areas. Here's a look at some of the hardest-hit cities, according to GasBuddy, an app that tracks fuel demand, prices and outages.

content.plaintext:
Nearly three-quarters — 73% — of gas stations in Pensacola, Florida, are impacted.
About 72% of gas stations are reporting outages in Raleigh, North Carolina. 
Outages are impacting 71% of the stations in metro Charlotte, North Carolina.
Nearly 60% of stations are impacted in Atlanta.
content.richtext:
• Nearly three-quarters — 73% — of gas stations in Pensacola, Florida, are impacted.
  • About 72% of gas stations are reporting outages in Raleigh, North Carolina.
  • Outages are impacting 71% of the stations in metro Charlotte, North Carolina.
  • Nearly 60% of stations are impacted in Atlanta.

headline.plaintext: City of Charlotte says it has enough fuel supply, but asks city employees to limit non-essential travel

byline.plaintext: From CNN’s Dianne Gallagher and Gregory Lemos
byline.richtext: From CNN’s Dianne Gallagher and Gregory Lemos

content.plaintext: The City of Charlotte, North Carolina, said Tuesday that while it has its own fuel reserve and enough fuel currently, it is asking city employees to limit non-essential travel “as a precautionary measure.”
content.richtext: The City of Charlotte, North Carolina, said Tuesday that while it has its own fuel reserve and enough fuel currently, it is asking city employees to limit non-essential travel “as a precautionary measure.”

content.plaintext: “There is enough fuel supply at this time, but the city is preparing for a prolonged interruption as a precaution to ensure essential services are maintained. City of Charlotte staff are being asked to limit non-essential travel as a precautionary measure,” Charlotte-Mecklenburg Emergency Management said in a statement Tuesday.
content.richtext: “There is enough fuel supply at this time, but the city is preparing for a prolonged interruption as a precaution to ensure essential services are maintained. City of Charlotte staff are being asked to limit non-essential travel as a precautionary measure,” Charlotte-Mecklenburg Emergency Management said in a statement Tuesday.

content.plaintext: In the statement, CMEM said it is actively monitoring the fallout from the cyber-attack on the Colonial Pipeline and urged the public to remain patient and avoid panic buying.
content.richtext: In the statement, CMEM said it is actively monitoring the fallout from the cyber-attack on the Colonial Pipeline and urged the public to remain patient and avoid panic buying.

content.plaintext: North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper issued a state of emergency Monday that temporarily suspends motor vehicle fuel regulations in the state.
content.richtext: North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper issued a state of emergency Monday that temporarily suspends motor vehicle fuel regulations in the state.

headline.plaintext: Consumer agency warns Americans against filling plastic bags with gasoline

content.plaintext: As some gas stations in the US Southeast are reporting outages fueled by panic-buying, the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission is warning Americans to only fill up containers approved to carry gasoline.
content.richtext: As some gas stations in the US Southeast are reporting outages fueled by panic-buying, the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission is warning Americans to only fill up containers approved to carry gasoline.

content.plaintext: Here are some of the agency's warnings on Twitter:
content.richtext: Here are some of the agency's warnings on Twitter:

oembed.html:
Do not fill plastic bags with gasoline.

— US Consumer Product Safety Commission (@USCPSC) May 12, 2021

Follow the gas canister manufacturer instructions for storing and transporting gasoline.

— US Consumer Product Safety Commission (@USCPSC) May 12, 2021

headline.plaintext: Demand for gas is prompting some people to panic buy. Here's how we got here.

content.plaintext: A growing number of gas stations along the East Coast are without fuel as nervous drivers aggressively fill up their tanks following a ransomware attack that shut down the Colonial Pipeline, a critical artery for gasoline.
content.richtext: A growing number of gas stations along the East Coast are without fuel as nervous drivers aggressively fill up their tanks following a ransomware attack that shut down the Colonial Pipeline, a critical artery for gasoline.

content.plaintext: If you're just reading in now, here's what you need to know:
content.richtext: If you're just reading in now, here's what you need to know:

content.plaintext:
About the pipeline: The pipeline system spans more than 5,500 miles and transports about 45% of all fuel consumed on the East Coast. It transports 2.5 million barrels per day of gasoline, diesel, jet fuel and home heating oil.
About the attack: The run on fuel began after a ransomware attack Friday shut down the Colonial Pipeline. The company said Monday it hopes to be substantially operational by the end of the week after a hack that authorities believe was carried out by a criminal group called DarkSide. As of Tuesday, most of the pipeline remained offline.
About the surge in demand: As of 7 am ET, 24.8% of all gas stations in North Carolina, 15.4% in Georgia and 15% in Virginia are without gasoline, according to GasBuddy. Outages were also reported in South Carolina (13.4%), Florida (4.2%), Maryland (3.5%) and Tennessee (2.8%)
content.richtext:
• About the pipeline: The pipeline system spans more than 5,500 miles and transports about 45% of all fuel consumed on the East Coast. It transports 2.5 million barrels per day of gasoline, diesel, jet fuel and home heating oil.
  • About the attack: The run on fuel began after a ransomware attack Friday shut down the Colonial Pipeline. The company said Monday it hopes to be substantially operational by the end of the week after a hack that authorities believe was carried out by a criminal group called DarkSide. As of Tuesday, most of the pipeline remained offline.
  • About the surge in demand: As of 7 am ET, 24.8% of all gas stations in North Carolina, 15.4% in Georgia and 15% in Virginia are without gasoline, according to GasBuddy. Outages were also reported in South Carolina (13.4%), Florida (4.2%), Maryland (3.5%) and Tennessee (2.8%)

headline.plaintext: The US Energy secretary says there "should be no cause for hoarding gasoline"

content.plaintext: Some gas stations in the Southeast are running out of gas as Americans panic-buy following the Colonial Pipeline shutdown.
content.richtext: Some gas stations in the Southeast are running out of gas as Americans panic-buy following the Colonial Pipeline shutdown.

content.plaintext: But experts say now is not the time to panic.
content.richtext: But experts say now is not the time to panic.

content.plaintext: The best thing for car owners to do right now is take a deep breath and don't rush to fill your tanks unless you have to. A big part of the problem is panic, Tiffany Wright of AAA Carolinas said. "We are our own worst enemy in this situation because we are over-consuming at the pump."
content.richtext: The best thing for car owners to do right now is take a deep breath and don't rush to fill your tanks unless you have to. A big part of the problem is panic, Tiffany Wright of AAA Carolinas said. "We are our own worst enemy in this situation because we are over-consuming at the pump."

content.plaintext: Energy Secretary Jennifer Granholm pleaded with Americans not to hoard gas as the pipeline attempts to resume operations.
content.richtext: Energy Secretary Jennifer Granholm pleaded with Americans not to hoard gas as the pipeline attempts to resume operations.

content.plaintext: "Let me emphasize that much as there was no cause for say, hoarding toilet paper at the beginning of the pandemic, there should be no cause for hoarding gasoline," Granholm said during Tuesday's White House press briefing, "especially in light of the fact that the pipeline should be substantially operational by the end of this week and over the weekend."
content.richtext: "Let me emphasize that much as there was no cause for say, hoarding toilet paper at the beginning of the pandemic, there should be no cause for hoarding gasoline," Granholm said during Tuesday's White House press briefing, "especially in light of the fact that the pipeline should be substantially operational by the end of this week and over the weekend."

headline.plaintext: Gasoline demand is two to four times normal in many markets, trade group says

paragraphs.text: A QuickTrip connivence store has bags on their pumps as the station has no gas on Tuesday, May 11, in Kennesaw, Georgia.

caption.richtext: A QuickTrip connivence store has bags on their pumps as the station has no gas on Tuesday, May 11, in Kennesaw, Georgia.
caption.plaintext: A QuickTrip connivence store has bags on their pumps as the station has no gas on Tuesday, May 11, in Kennesaw, Georgia.

content.plaintext: Some gas stations are being overwhelmed by intense demand for fuel following the shutdown of the Colonial Pipeline, an industry trade group told CNN Business on Wednesday.
content.richtext: Some gas stations are being overwhelmed by intense demand for fuel following the shutdown of the Colonial Pipeline, an industry trade group told CNN Business on Wednesday.

content.plaintext: “Demand has been two to four times normal in many markets and the system, even when it isn’t stressed, can’t support that,” Jeff Lenard, vice president of strategic industry initiatives at NACS, the leading trade group for convenience and fuel retailing, said in an email.
content.richtext: “Demand has been two to four times normal in many markets and the system, even when it isn’t stressed, can’t support that,” Jeff Lenard, vice president of strategic industry initiatives at NACS, the leading trade group for convenience and fuel retailing, said in an email.

content.plaintext: Lenard said the association has heard from retailers there are “definitely issues keeping ‘wet’” and called out images on social media showing people filling up not just their vehicles but any container available.
content.richtext: Lenard said the association has heard from retailers there are “definitely issues keeping ‘wet’” and called out images on social media showing people filling up not just their vehicles but any container available.

content.plaintext: “That is a big problem,” he said. “Not only does that take away from fuel from those who need it, it also creates concern over transport and storage, wherever they are going. Just because you have something with a lid doesn’t mean you need to fill it with fuel.”
content.richtext: “That is a big problem,” he said. “Not only does that take away from fuel from those who need it, it also creates concern over transport and storage, wherever they are going. Just because you have something with a lid doesn’t mean you need to fill it with fuel.”

headline.plaintext: Some southeastern gas stations are running out of gas. Here are the hardest-hit states.

paragraphs.text: Customers wait in line to purchase fuel at the Duck-Thru in Scotland Neck, North Carolina, on Tuesday, May 11.
Robert Willett/The News & Observer via AP

content.richtext: Gas stations in the southeastern United States face significant outages Wednesday as the Colonial Pipeline shutdown stretches into a sixth day, sparking panic-buying that is exacerbating the supply crunch.

content.richtext: Here's a look at the states reporting the most outages as of 7 a.m. ET today, according to GasBuddy, an app that tracks fuel demand, prices and outages:

15.4% in Georgia

3.5% in Maryland

  • 15.4% in Georgia
  • 15% in Virginia

content.plaintext: Experts and officials pleaded with Americans not to hoard gasoline in the wake of the ransomware attack on the Colonial Pipeline because overconsumption will only make the situation worse.
content.richtext: Experts and officials pleaded with Americans not to hoard gasoline in the wake of the ransomware attack on the Colonial Pipeline because overconsumption will only make the situation worse.
